misconceptions.inferred_category_name: Parallel Arrays Lose Alignment During Sorting
misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that sorting the scores array automatically keeps the corresponding names in the same relative positions (i.e., that the name-score pairing is preserved even if only the scores array is sorted).
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, `Arrays.sort(z)` sorts only the `int[] z` array in place. It does not know about the `names` array, so it will not reorder `names` to match the new order of scores. With parallel arrays, you must swap both arrays together during sorting (or sort indices/objects) to keep relationships intact.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Wrong output: the printed name may not be the student who actually has the highest score (name-score mismatch), even though the printed score is the maximum.

misconceptions.inferred_category_name: Parallel Array Index Desynchronization After Sorting
misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that when you sort one of two parallel arrays independently, the indices remain synchronized with the other array. They think that after sorting the scores array, the name at index n-1 will still correspond to the highest score at index n-1, just as it did before the sort.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: The student fails to understand that sorting one array does not automatically reorder the corresponding elements in the other array. In Java, when you call Arrays.sort(z), only the scores array is rearranged; the names array remains in its original order. The correspondence between names and scores is broken after the independent sort. The correct approach requires either sorting both arrays in tandem (by swapping elements in both when needed) or tracking indices to maintain the parallel relationship.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Wrong output - the program will print the last name in the original input order paired with the highest score, rather than the actual name of the student who earned that score. For the sample input, it would print 'Charlie (92)' instead of 'Bob (92)'.

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that sorting one array (the scores) will automatically rearrange the elements of a separate parallel array (the names) to maintain the relationship between a student and their score.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, arrays are distinct and independent memory objects. The Arrays.sort() method only manipulates the specific array reference passed to it; it lacks any mechanism to detect or maintain logical associations with other arrays. To sort parallel arrays, a manual sorting algorithm (like Bubble Sort) must swap elements in both arrays simultaneously, or the data must be encapsulated in an object.

misconceptions.inferred_category_name: Sorting one parallel array automatically reorders the other
misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that sorting the `scores` array with `Arrays.sort(z)` will keep the `names` array aligned to the same students (i.e., that the corresponding `names` entries will move along with their scores).
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, `Arrays.sort(z)` only reorders the elements of the array passed to it. It does not (and cannot) automatically rearrange a separate parallel array (`names`) to preserve pairings. To keep name–score associations, you must swap both arrays together during a custom sort, or store pairs in a single structure (e.g., a `Student` object) and sort that.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Wrong output (prints the highest score correctly, but often prints the wrong student name for that score). It only appears correct when the input names happen to already be in ascending-score order.

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that sorting the scores array (z) will automatically keep the data aligned with the names array (y). They think that by sorting z and then accessing y[n-1] and z[n-1], they will get the correct name-score pair for the highest score, without needing to apply the same sort operation to both arrays.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: The student fails to understand that parallel arrays maintain correspondence through indices. When you sort one array independently, the correspondence is broken. The same permutation must be applied to both arrays simultaneously, or a different approach (like pairing objects or tracking indices) must be used. Here, sorting only the scores array means the names array is left in its original order while the scores are rearranged.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Wrong output. With the sample input (Alice 85, Bob 92, Charlie 78), after sorting z becomes [78, 85, 92]. The program outputs 'Top student: Charlie (92)' instead of the correct 'Top student: Bob (92)', because y[2]='Charlie' no longer corresponds to z[2]=92.

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that sorting one array (scores) will automatically rearrange the corresponding elements in a separate but logically related array (names) to maintain their relationship.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, parallel arrays are independent data structures with no intrinsic link. Built-in sorting methods like Arrays.sort() only manipulate the specific array passed to them; they do not possess 'knowledge' of other arrays that the programmer intends to stay aligned via index. Consequently, sorting one array breaks the index-to-index mapping between the two arrays.
